title: Tom Swift and His Outpost in Space
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104354im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ts_page2_6360.jpg)

This typeface looked a lot like Century Expanded, but the capital J that goes below the line eliminates that.

The italic capital Q eliminates Baskerville or Bulmer. I'm pretty sure this isn't Imprint, because it doesn't look at all like Caslon. (Similarly, it isn't the Phemister Old Style.)

I think I should be able to recognize this typeface immediately, but I'm embarassed to admit that I can't.

Also, I see that it is not Number Twenty-One from Linotype; that doesn't have a descending J, and it has a different type of Q in the italic.

Font: 

 Linotype Baskerville 

Solved By: 

 [bowfinpw](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104354/http:/typophile.com/user/2088 "View user profile.")
author: quadibloc

comments.content:
Looking at the Baskerville types in Mac McGrew's book "American Metal Typefaces of the Twentieth Century", this looks like the Linotype version of Baskerville. The italic 'k' is I think the key to separate it from the Monotype and ATF versions. It also has that unusually long J, and the italic Q seems to match.

- Mike Yanega

Although I haven't been able to fully verify this, as the page with Baskerville on it isn't in the preview of "The Type Specimen Book" by V&M Typographical on Google Books, and Baskerville isn't in "The Linotype Manual", looking at _Intertype_ Baskerville on [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104354/http:/www.urbancottageindustries.com/blog/print-library/intertype-faces/baskerville-font/) leaves me little doubt that you're absolutely right.

Ah, the Linotype specimen in question is online [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104354/http:/www.linotypesetting.com/html/content/mats.php).
